awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Reserach:  Geotextile Tubes for the Sustainable Dewatering
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this research project is to develop polysaccharide-based alternatives to synthetic polyacrylamide-derived polymer flocculants, and to explore the possibility of using natural fiber-based geotextiles for the dewatering application. The dredging of sediments from harbors, lakes, canals, tailings ponds, and other bodies of water has attracted a significant amount of public interest in recent years. Dredged sediments are generally high in water content that must be disposed of in environmentally and economically sustainable ways. The handling and disposal of these materials typically require dewatering, the process whereby liquid is removed from the materials to increase the percent solids to acceptable levels. A decade ago, the dewatering of high water content materials (1-10 percent dry solids) was performed almost exclusively with settling ponds, mechanical presses, and centrifuges. More recently, geotextile tubes have been successfully used for dewatering high water content materials by many industries. The need to maximize the retention of materials and minimize the time required for dewatering has led to the common addition of synthetic cationic or anionic acrylamide-derived polymers in geotextile tube applications. While these polymers have become an essential component of geotextile tube dewatering, concerns exist regarding their safety. In addition, there is a wide disparity in the performance indices and test methods that are currently being used to evaluate geotextile tube performance. This project will be the first systematic study of its kind which aims to develop polysaccharide-based alternatives to synthetic polyacrylamide-derived polymer flocculants, and to explore the possibility of using natural fiber-based geotextiles for the dewatering application. The acute toxicity of natural and synthetic polymer flocculants will be tested using the fish embryo toxicity test with zebrafish. The study will also include bench-scale and pilot-scale simulation tests on sediment with clay minerals and organic matter. The tests will be critically evaluated and a new performance standard for the evaluation of geotextile tubes for dewatering sediments will be developed. A mathematical model which incorporates the fundamental properties of sediment, polymers, and geotextiles will be developed to evaluate the long-term performance of geotextile tubes.

This project addresses an important problem related to the dredging, the dewatering of dredged materials in an efficient, safe and sustainable manner. Webinars will be developed to provide an overview of the use of geotextile tubes, their benefits, and the findings from this study. The webinars will be advertised through national organizations, such as the North American Geosynthetics Society (NAGS) and the American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE). The PIs will present their research results at the annual ASTM D-35 committee meetings and will take an active role in developing performance standards for the bench-scale tests used for the dewatering evaluation of geotextile tubes. Two middle school teachers will be involved in the project. The teachers will develop teaching modules, in collaboration with the PIs, which will be used to disseminate information on geotextile tubes to middle-school students.

por.por_cntn:
Dewatering of sediments from harbors, lakes, canals, and tailings ponds has attracted significant public interest in the US and around the world. Geotextile tube dewatering is a relatively new technology that has seen tremendous growth in recent years.  Although geotextile tubes are considered efficient and cost effective, more work is needed to assure their continued growth as an effective and sustainable dewatering technology.  Recently, more than 2.1 million cubic yards of sediment were dredged from Onondaga Lake in Syracuse, New York.  The sediments were dewatered and contained in hundreds of geotextile tubes stacked more than 30 feet high.  To date, this project has been the largest application of geotextile tubes in North America. 

Although synthetic polyacrylamide-based polymers are used in the majority of geotextile tube dewatering projects, concerns exist regarding their cost and safety.  There is also a need to explore the development of natural fiber geotextile tubes to take advantage of the unique properties of natural fibers and their ability to biodegrade.  This study, undertaken by a multi-disciplinary team with close collaboration with industrial advisory members, evaluated the effectiveness of starch-based polymers, natural fibers made from peanut shells and jute, and jute fiber nonwoven geotextiles for geotextile tube dewatering.  Hundreds of small- and large-scale tests were conducted using 20 different sediments, of which 16 were from various rivers, lakes, and tailings ponds in the US and other were fine sand, silt, clay and organic soil. Thirty different synthetic and jute fiber geotextiles and four different types of natural and synthetic fibers (peanut shell, jute, kraft pulp, and nylon) were used to enhance the dewatering rate and absorption of heavy metals present in the heavy metal contaminated slurry.

The bench-scale and pilot-scale test results for the 8 specially prepared cationic starches were found to be effective flocculants.  In comparison to the cationic polyacrylamides (CPAMs), larger amounts of starches were required, but resulted in cleaner effluents and drier filter cakes.  It was found that natural short fibers (peanut shell and jute) in small quantities (less than 0.5% by weight) were effective in enhancing dewatering rates and absorbing heavy metals, such as lead, copper, zinc, and cadmium from slurries.  Small-scale tests showed that nonwoven jute geotextiles have similar dewatering and sediment retention as synthetic nonwoven geotextiles.

This study resulted in several new techniques. It was found that small-scale centrifuge tests conducted on sediment slurries with and without flocculants could be used to predict solids content of full-scale geotextile tubes. This was proven for two geotextile tube dewatering projects in New York and Illinois.  It was also found that the streaming current method could be used to measure polymer amounts in geotextile tube effluents.  This technique has been used in several projects by the industry.   

New test equipment was designed and a large-scale geotextile tube facility was developed and used for this research. To evaluate the role of sediment characteristics, geotextile properties, nature of fiber, type of polymer, and sample size, many experimental techniques were used. This rich experimental data will be shared with other researchers.  During this study, 22 undergraduate and graduate students were trained: 9 female, 1 Hispanic male, and 1 African American female. Many of these students won awards for their presentations, received competitive fellowships, and coauthored 23 papers with the research team. Several of the undergraduate students pursued graduate education in engineering at prestigious institutions.

The research team established partnerships with several geosynthetic manufacturers, national testing laboratories, consultants, and colleagues from other academic institutions. The results of this study were widely disseminated at national and international conferences, and local ASCE chapter meetings.  Twenty-three papers have been published in prestigious journals and conference proceedings. Several hands-on experiments were developed for middle school students and teachers, who were invited every summer to explore the nature of sediment, the magic of polymers, and how to clean large water bodies.
